prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author (the wife) is in the wrong in this situation. The main issue is that the husband set up his office in their bedroom, leading to conflicts because the wife can't use the room without disturbing his work. She suggested the basement, which is quieter but he prefers the view. Now, she feels restricted in her ability to use the bedroom for personal needs, like showering or working.

First, I need to understand both sides. The husband's job requires him to be undisturbed for conference calls, which is important for his work. However, the wife also works from home and has responsibilities with the kids and housework. They have space in the basement, which would allow her more freedom. But he chose the bedroom instead because of the view.

The key points here are about shared space and mutual responsibilities. When both partners work from home and have childcare duties, setting boundaries is crucial. The husband's decision to take over the bedroom might be seen as selfish if it's causing significant disruption. On the other hand, the wife is trying to balance work and home duties, which is a lot.

I think the wife isn't wrong here. The husband has the option to use the basement, which would minimize disruption. By choosing the bedroom, he's limiting her ability to function. The wife is setting boundaries by saying she can't guarantee silence there. It's about respecting each other's workspaces and responsibilities. The husband's preference for the view shouldn't override the wife's need to manage her household tasks and work. So the answer should be B, the author isn't in the wrong.
